Detailed Description

The ATimer class wraps a native FreeRTOS timer handle (xTimerHandle). The application must subclass this class and implements the pure virtual method ATimer::OnExpired. The ATimer::OnExpired method is called when the timer period expires. This class conforms to the iFreeRTOSProtocol protocol, so the application has to call the object ATimer::Create method in order to allocate the underling FreeRTOS resource before using it.

See also:
Software Timer documentation in the FreeRTOS web site.
Date:
Jun 16, 2011
Author:
Stefano Oliveri (STF12.net) E-Mail: software@stf12.net

Constructor & Destructor Documentation

ATimer::ATimer ( )

The default constructor. It initializes the object without attaching it to a native FreeRTOS handle. Call the Create method to allocate a timer handle and attach it to the object.

ATimer::ATimer ( xTimerHandle  handleTimer)

Create a ATimer instance and attach it to a valid handle.

Parameters:
handleTimera valid timer handle.
virtual ATimer::~ATimer ( ) [virtual]

Delete the native FreeRTOS timer.

Member Function Documentation

void ATimer::Attach ( xGenericHandle  handle) [virtual]

Attach the object to a given FreeRTOS handle. A previous attached handle is deleted and its resource are freed.

Parameters:
handlespecifies a native FreeRTOS handle.

Implements IFreeRTOSObj.

xGenericHandle ATimer::Detach ( ) [virtual]

Usually a FreeRTOS handle is disposed and his resource freed when the attached object is deleted. Call this method to keep the handle alive.

Returns:
the native FreeRTOS handle. This handle is valid after the object is disposed.

Implements IFreeRTOSObj.

Check if the object is attached to a valid FreRTOS native handle.

Returns:

ATimer::operator xTimerHandle ( ) const [inline]

Retrieve the native FreeRTOS timer handle attached to this object.

the native FreeRTOS timer handle attached to this object.
